Kim Reynolds (R-IA) is Interviewed About the Situation in Iowa and How Technology Companies Could Create Opportunities There; Awaiting August Jobs Report; WSJ: States to Launch Google & Facebook Antitrust Probes; U.S.-China Trade Tensions; Hurricane Dorian Lingers Off North Carolina Coast; 130K Jobs Added In August2019-09-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:21:22ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA8:00 AM ESTRo Khanna, Kim Reynolds, Joanie Courtney, Stephen Moore, John Lonski, Stephanie PomboyNEWSFinancial090603cb.231Rep. Ro Khanna (D-CA) is Interviewed About What He Wants To Do In Terms of Rural Jobs Across the Country, Created by Tech; Gov. Kim Reynolds (R-IA) is Interviewed About the Situation in Iowa and How Technology Companies Could Create Opportunities There; Awaiting August Jobs Report; WSJ: States to Launch Google & Facebook Antitrust Probes; U.S.-China Trade Tensions; Hurricane Dorian Lingers Off North Carolina Coast; 130K Jobs Added In AugustMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Jon Hilsenrath, Jeff Flock, Edward Lawrence, Charles Payne, Kristina Partsinevelos, Dani Klupenger, Stuart Varney

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: a third of a percent. This, on top of yesterday's big rally. The major indices finished up across the board, largely due to the U.S. and Chinese officials confirming a fresh round of face-to-face trade talks, are now set for early October. DowIndustrials were up 372 points, the NASDAQ, up 140 points, 1 and 3 quarters percent.

In Europe this morning, markets look like this, we did get German industrial production out, this morning, for the month of July, and the Eurozone growth fell by 50 percent in the second quarter, the latest signs of slowing economic growth in the Eurozone. FT-100 down 3 points, CAC Quarante in Paris is up 7, and the DAX Index in Germany is up 75, about one half -- two-thirds of one percent, rather.

In Asia overnight, take a look at the numbers, the Shanghai in China was up half a percent, China cut the amount of cash that banks must hold as reserves that injected some stimulus liquidity into the economy there, which is slowing down.

This, as more protests are planned in Hong Kong this weekend, even after officials pulled the controversial extradition bill. Hong Kong democracy advocate Jimmy Lai, joined me last hour, here's what he said.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JIMMY LAI, TYCOON, HONG KONG TECH: If the economy goes down and trigger, that emotion can explode. That will be a big problem for China.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: This morning, Fitch downgraded Hong Kong due to the continued unrest. We are looking at the Hong Kong situation, worsen, despite the extradition bill because they want autonomy. Now, they want to be able to vote for their own leadership, as they were promised, under microscope.

The state attorneys general formally launching antitrust probe into big tech companies, Facebook and Google, the concerns over user data, coming up. All those stories coming up this Friday morning, for a special jobs' day special coverage.

The host of "MAKING MONEY" on FOX Business is here, Charles Payne, FOX Business Network's Dagen McDowell and MacroMavens' president, Stephanie Pomboy, Moody's Capital Markets chief economist, John Lonski, great to see everybody, and welcome Stephanie and Charles, good to see you.

Numbers out in 30 minutes, going to have real ramifications with the Fed meeting right around the corner. Charles, what do you think?

CHARLES PAYNE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: I think 175. I'm looking for more participation, last month -- the last report we had, participation was amazing, particularly black Americans, 300 --230,000 came back into the labor force, still want to see year-over-year wage growth and a 3 percent, maybe 3.3, 3.4 percent. That's -- those are the numbers I'm looking for.

Worried about manufacturing, of course, worried about construction in those goods-producing jobs.

BARTIROMO: All right. I want to get everybody's take, coming up, but we want to also look at jobs in America from another standpoint, and the August jobs' report is due out in under 30 minutes, economists are expecting 158,000 jobs added to the economy.

So, Charles is expecting even higher than that. The unemployment rate is expected to hold steady at 3.7 percent. My next guest hopes to see positive numbers. They are working to encourage technology companies to create jobs in rural America.

Joining me right now is California Congressman Ro Khanna, along with Iowa Governor Kim Reynolds. It is good to have you both with us. Thank you so much for being here. And Congressman Khanna, let me kick it off with you, tell me what you want to do here, in terms of rural jobs, across the country, created by tech?

REP. RO KHANNA (D-CA): Well, I've been very pleased to partner with Governor Reynolds and the local stakeholders in Jefferson, Iowa. We have had a number of Silicon Valley companies offer scholarships with Des Moines Community College, and offer a pathway for folks to get trained in digital marketing, in software design and be able to get jobs.

And they are going to be able to stay in the communities they grew up in. I really believe that Jefferson, Iowa can be a model for the country, in showing how we can create a technology opportunity in rural America.

BARTIROMO: Yes, you know, it's interesting because you've got technology taking us forward, certainly, making our live better in so many ways, but there's also that worry about privacy, right, Congressman? I mean, just today, we're talking all about facial recognition, for example, and you know, there are some colleagues on -- of yours, that are worried about things like ring.

The company that has that doorbell that you can see, you know, the camera. Amazon owns the doorbell camera company. It's facing questions from Senator Edward Markey, over its partnerships with police departments around the country and tracking citizens.

KHANNA: Well, Maria, there's no doubt that technology can be abused. I have put forward an internet bill of rights to be able to protect people's privacy and to make sure that technology isn't misused in engaging in profiling or discrimination.

But I think the challenge of our time is to maximize the positives of technology to allow people access to jobs that are going to have a technical component while minimizing the harm.

BARTIROMO: Governor, where do you sit on this? Tell us the situation in Iowa and how technology companies could create opportunities there?

GOV. KIM REYNOLDS (R-IA): Well, I'm really excited about the forge in this dynamic project and the opportunities that it provides for Iowans, especially in rural Iowa. I appreciate Congressman Ro Khanna and his involvement in really helping bring jobs to rural America. I want to give a shout out to Accenture for going beyond our urban centers and taking this model into rural Iowa.

We have a diverse in growing economy. We have one of the lowest unemployment rates in the country. And so, this is an opportunity not only to make sure that we are seeing that the success that Iowa is seeing, is happening all across our state and not just in pockets. And I believe with this model, it's an example that we can scale in rural communities all across Iowa and this country.

BARTIROMO: So, we have been talking all morning about the jobs report, we're going to get the numbers in 25 minutes, but one issue is that people need to be retrained, right? There's a real skills gap going on over there, throughout the country.

REYNOLDS: Yes.

BARTIROMO: So, what do you want to say to people out there who, you know, maybe it's a -- you know, a construction worker, a truck driver, whatever, they don't know anything about coding. They don't know anything about some of this technology new, you know, million-dollar words that we're talking about. How are they going to thrive?

REYNOLDS: Well, we want to make sure we start and have that pipeline in middle school and high school so that we are training our young people to be adaptive, to be lifelong learners, but we have a program in Iowa that we launched a couple years ago, and that we're really -- it's -- we're implementing it right now and it's called Future ReadyIowa.

And it has a goal of having 70 percent of Iowans, in the workforce, have either education or training beyond high school by the year 2025. We've put funding into that so that we can help not only with the pipeline for our K-12, but to work with our adult learners to provide that support system, to help them get the skills, to match them up with the jobs that we have available in the state right now.

These are great careers to help them be lifelong learners and the -- I believe, the hub, like the forge, is an opportunity to -- you know, to serve as a launchpad, to retrain, to help kids get the skills to fill the jobs, so --

BARTIROMO: I think it's an important point.

REYNOLDS: -- we're seeing this happen all over the state. Pardon?

BARTIROMO: So, I think it's an important point that you make about older workers, because, that's the group, white collar too, by the way, who are being left behind in some -- in some regard. Congressman Khanna, let me ask you about these antitrust investigations, the Texas attorney general set to lead an effort, looking into Google and digital advertising, this, according to "The Wall Street Journal."

New York attorney general is also overseeing a review of Facebook and personal data concerns. These investigations could expand to other companies. What do you want to see in terms of regulation, on big tech, knowing that these companies are more powerful today than they've ever been?

KHANNA: Well, I think we, obviously, have to enforce antitrust law and make sure that these platforms are competitive, that they aren't privileging their own products, but we also need to make sure that we are innovative. America leads the world in innovation. Our technology is far superior to any tech company in Europe. And our real competition is China.

And so, I want to make sure that we have strong antitrust enforcement, but I also want to make sure that America leads the world in technology. And a quick point, I think you're absolutely right, Maria, that there are going to be jobs in all different industries, manufacturing, construction, logistics --

BARTIROMO: That's right.

KHANNA: -- not everyone has to go become a coder, but everyone is going to need some technology skill --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KHANNA: -- even in the industry that they may work in.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's absolutely right. The skills training is really important at this moment in time. Does it bother you that Google has an A.I. lab in China? I mean, look, this China fight with the U.S., is getting deeper. Retail giant, Target, is telling suppliers ahead of the September 1st tariff hike, they'd have to pay for additional costs, not consumers. Beijing is (ph) also feeling the tariff pinch, a report from the Tokyo investment bank, Nomura, says that countries like Vietnam and South Korea are benefiting the most from the trade impasse.

And we know, Governor, that Google walked away from a contract with the Pentagon, Project Maven, and yet, it has an A.I. lab in China. Is there any reason to believe that China will try to dictate or meddle in the U.S. elections through Google?

REYNOLDS: Is that to me?

BARTIROMO: Yes.

REYNOLDS: Oh, I'm sorry. OK. Well, listen, I think that's something that we need to be mindful of. We know that China has been a bad actor. We need to hold them accountable, and that's what we're trying to do. And so, it's important that we take this seriously, and that we, you know, stay firm in what we're trying to do through the negotiations of -- with China, but they have a history of being a bad actor.

They -- it's intellectual property and technology transfer is a cost of doing business. Our businesses are aware of that. And so, we need to hold them accountable.

BARTIROMO: I'm just -- I'm just wondering about Google, Congressman Khanna, because, you know, you heard Peter Thiel's comments, right? I mean, Peter Thiel wrote an op-ed and he said it's a national security risk, that Google has an A.I. lab in China, what do you think about that? Any worries?

KHANNA: Well, I agree with Governor Reynolds that China has been stealing intellectual property. There's no doubt about that. We need to protect our most sensitive technology from going to China. I don't think we ought to allow China, access, to our most sensitive technology.

What we also need to do, as a country, is invest in the technologies of the future, Artificial Intelligence, quantum computing --

BARTIROMO: Are we doing enough of that?

KHANNA: -- and make sure America leads --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KHANNA: -- in the industries of the future.

BARTIROMO: You're right, especially as China wants to be number one in all of those industries, so you wonder if we are, in fact, doing enough. It's great to have this conversation with you both, and it's great to see you both working together on this very important project. Thank you, Congressman Ro Khanna and Governor Kim Reynolds, good to see you both.

REYNOLDS: Thank you.

KHANNA: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you. Have a good day. Coming up, Dorian's devastation, high winds, life-threatening storm surges, menacing the Carolina coast, leaving hundreds of thousands without power. We're going to take you there, live, next.

And we are just under 20 minutes away from the August jobs report, we're breaking that down, see if it's going to impact markets with the highs of the morning, up 118 now in the Dow. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. We are tracking Hurricane Dorian. The storm weakening to a category 1 now but it's still packing a punch, as it turns off the North Carolina coast. High winds, torrential downpours, knocking out power to thousands of people. Jeff Flock is live this morning in Awendaw, South Carolina with the very latest. Did I say that right, Jeff, Awendaw?

JEFF FLOCK, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: You pronounce that right. Nice work.

BARTIROMO: Oh, good.

FLOCK: That's not easy down here. The locals are very particular. So, it's a small little fishing village here. And this is characteristic of the damage perhaps that you see behind me. But I have breaking news for you, Maria, Hatteras, Cape Hatteras is now in the eye of the storm. If we take a look at the radar and the track, perhaps we can see that. This does not, though, technically constitute a landfall. According National Hurricane Center, the very center of the eye must go over land in order to call it a landfall. So, at this point, we still don't have a landfall for Hurricane Dorian.

But that category 1 storm, as you point out, still lashing the coast up there, causing all kinds of havoc. Although, when it's said and done, it appears because a lot of communities have already been in the eyewall, the kind of damage you're going to see after it will be the kind that you see behind me, which is essentially trees uprooted, you know, some signs knocked down, but nothing major, catastrophic. So, I think a positive story there of the landfall or the almost landfall of Hurricane Dorian. Maria?

BARTIROMO: All right, Jeff, thank you so much. Jeff Flock this morning with incredible reporting this whole week. We are minutes away from the August jobs report. Everything you need to know ahead of that release when we come right back. Markets at the high of the morning right now, up 129 points on the Dow. 14 points higher in the S&P, and the NASDAQ up 30 points. Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. The August jobs report due out in just 10 minutes' time. Economists are expecting you to show 150,000 jobs were added to the economy in the month of August with the unemployment rate holding steady at 3.7 percent.

We have an all-star panel this morning to break it all down. Chief Workforce Analyst at EmployBridge Joanie Courtney is with us this morning. She knows exactly where all the jobs are. Senior writer for The Wall Street Journal, Jon Hilsenrath knows exactly where rates are going. And the former Wall Street Journal editorial board member and Trumponomics co- author, Stephen Moore, knows everything about the economy. And then, I've got an incredible group here on set. Thanks, everybody for joining us. Stephanie Pomboy, let me ask you what's most important in this report from your standpoint?

STEPHANIE POMBOY, PRESIDENT, MACROMAVENS: Well, I guess I was ranting and raving all last year about how profits were going to go into recession. And profits are the number one input into employment hiring decisions. Lo and behold, profits are in recession now. And it wasn't some great crystal ball that I had, it's that the government profit numbers were already much weaker than S&P, which speaks to an underlying weakness in the economy that's been in place long before all this tariff talk.

So, I think we're starting to see that impact. You've seen a slowdown in growth and employment, which, you know, would naturally follow this slowdown in profit growth. So, I think that continues. urn:contentItem:5PSX-TCH1-DXH2-60MF-00000-00Rep. Ro Khanna, D-Calif. is interviewed on BB TV.2017-10-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:21:22ZLexisNexisBLOOMBERG TV12:00 AM ESTRep. Ro Khanna, D-Calif.NEWSInternational102381cb.550Rep. Ro Khanna, D-Calif. is interviewed on BB TV.Rep. Ro Khanna, D-Calif.

Rep. Ro Khanna, D-Calif. discusses politics.

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

REP. RO KHANNA, D-CALIF., IS INTERVIEWED ON BB TV

OCTOBER 23, 2017

SPEAKERS: REP. RO KHANNA, D-CALIF.

EMILY CHANG, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] EMILY CHANG, BLOOMBERG HOST: Well, on November 1st, three of the top tech firms will testify before congress. Lawmakers want them to answer publicly about Russia interference in the 2016 U.S. elections.

But one congressman isn't waiting until them to challenge Silicon Valley. Representative Ro Khanna of California has spend a stirring Op-Ed in the Washington Post titled "Trump beat Silicon Valley at its own game. Now, it must prove itself."

In it, he takes big tech to task over a variety of issues from election meddling to diversity and more, he joins me now from Washington. Representative Khanna, thank you so much for joining us.

So you say Trump used the tools of technology to win despite Silicon Valley's overwhelming support for Hillary Clinton.

It's almost as if Trump bested tech leaders at the game they invented, how so?

REP. RO KHANNA, D-CALIF.: Well, Trump was very effective in using Twitter and Facebook to get passionate support to get his message out.

But a lot of these platforms, of course, we're abused. They amplified fake voices, extreme voices that pretended to be 10,000 people even though there was only one person they've crafted in false news.

And so tech needs to help figure out how to solve some of these issues. We know it can empower individuals in extraordinary ways but we need to fix the excess that we saw in the 2016 election cycle.

CHANG: Right, you say tech tools should strengthen not weaken democracy and Russia interference aside. Someone argue that, you know, social media has dramatically increase the number of voices that are being heard. You know, can tech companies really be responsible for all of this?

KHANNA: Well, I actually think tech has played a very positive role overall. I mean, it gave a rise -- give rise to Barack Obama and to Bernie Sanders.

I often joke at town halls that the average person could have more of a voice by having a clever tweet or Facebook posts than I can by speaking to an empty chamber in congress.

So tech has empowered individuals in extraordinary ways, but that said there are things that now that they have become a platform where almost 50 percent of Americans get their news there that they need to do.

One if having some basic differentiation between fact and opinion on newspapers, TV stations like yours have third-party verification and they independently checked facts.

There can be third-party verification on some of the posts. They should look at providing perhaps an alternative perspective if viewers want that alternative perspective.

They just need to look at what their journalistic responsibilities can be without suppressing the freedom of expression.

And I'm encouraged that the number of tech companies are doing that and that dialogue has begun.

CHANG: You wonder though how far these companies can go? How well companies can distinguish between fact and opinion when our own president may have a different opinion of the facts than the facts?

KHANNA: I agree, it's a very difficult issue. But there are independent third-party sites which can at least rate content so if some part one that's out there saying the sky is green or that, you know, Barack Obama isn't an American citizen.

They could at least have a rating and verification. Just like newspapers do, just like television stations do where they could provide a link to say, "Here are some alternative perspectives if you saw the truth."

I think these tech companies -- tech company and social media is very different than television.

Television is an as interactive, people aren't responding to me. It's a broadcast, two individuals and tech is a person-to-person communication.

So tech can't be responsible for every single post in the content of every single post.

That said they do need to move towards adopting some journalistic standards of third-party verification, fact verification so they could give users an informed perspective.

CHANG: That said, I wonder how much can we rely on companies to do the right thing or whatever is in the best interest of society rather than what's in the best interest of their business.

And how much should the government actually be in charge of figuring out whether there's Russia interference on these platforms? Should there be government regulation?

KHANNA: Well, I think there are two different questions. In terms of the best interest of society, I think that was Silicon Valley's tradition with David Packard and Hewlett-Packard and some of the early founders, Andy Grove.

They talked about building technology in a way that would help society, help empower people.

And if you talk to tech leaders that's what they really hope that their platforms would help improve communication, lead to a more connected world, create more jobs.

Tim Cook recently said that business leaders have a moral responsibility to care about education and jobs.

Sundar Pichai recently announced a one billion dollar initiative to prepare folks for the tech jobs of the future.

And so I think there is an ongoing awareness with tech leaders that they have to care about their contribution to jobs in places that don't have them and to the democratic conversation.

Given that they are some of the largest companies in the nation and some of them have such great responsibility in so many viewers.

On the Russia issue, I think their -- we definitely need better intelligent sharing between tech companies and the government so that they can get advance notice if there is suspicious activity and act on it.

And tech companies need to help adapt exceptional processing to look at false accounts or bad accounts, bad actors, the way some bank (INAUDIBLE)

Some of it is hiring more people, but even if they hire a thousand of more people given the volume, they probably need investments in machine learning and artificial intelligence to be able to do some of that work.

So I'm hopeful a lot of it will be tech coming to its own conclusion but some -- there will probably be a role for congress and lawmakers as well to have constructive rules that tech can follow.

CHANG: Similarly, you talk about the importance of increasing diversity at these companies upward mobility, is this something that you think companies can do on their own?

We know that the representation of women in minorities at tech companies is very low or is this something that the government should regulate?

KHANNA: Well, I think it's in the tech companies own advantage to expand their imagination in recruiting. Let me give you a concrete example, 45 percent of African-Americans who have STEM degrees go to a historically black college or university, 45 percent.

Now, if tech companies want to expand where there's talent, they should form partnerships with some of the best historically black colleges and universities in the country and recruit from there.

The NFL in the 1960s, the Oakland Raiders did that. They started recruiting at the HPCUs and it gave them a whole competitive advantage over the rest of the teams in the NFL.

At the time where it have such scarcity for engineers and tech talent and everyone is concern that Google and Facebook and Apple is getting all the talent, expanding the pool and going to places to like HPCUs would make a difference. Same with in -- you know, go ahead.

CHANG: But the question -- the question is whether or not they should, it's whether the government should force them to do so or legislate, you know, various requirements for representation of women in minorities in your ranks?

KHANNA: Well, I'm not for quote our government regulating that but I do think government can make investment and women's schools that focus on STEM and HPCUs in providing greater opportunities and pathways in getting incentives for corporate mentorship for women leaders.

I think government can incentivize the creation of the pipeline and in getting people in to those leadership ranks.

But I don't think they should regulate a number of that tech companies have to fill as a quote I think that will be going too far.

CHANG: All right. Representative Ro Khanna, thank you so much for joining us. Great to have you here on the show.

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

REP. RO KHANNA, D-CALIF., IS INTERVIEWED ON BB TV

OCTOBER 23, 2017

SPEAKERS: REP. RO KHANNA, D-CALIF.

EMILY CHANG, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] EMILY CHANG, BLOOMBERG HOST: Well, on November 1st, three of the top tech firms will testify before congress. Lawmakers want them to answer publicly about Russia interference in the 2016 U.S. elections.

But one congressman isn't waiting until them to challenge Silicon Valley. Representative Ro Khanna of California has spend a stirring Op-Ed in the Washington Post titled "Trump beat Silicon Valley at its own game. Now, it must prove itself."

In it, he takes big tech to task over a variety of issues from election meddling to diversity and more, he joins me now from Washington. Representative Khanna, thank you so much for joining us.

So you say Trump used the tools of technology to win despite Silicon Valley's overwhelming support for Hillary Clinton.

It's almost as if Trump bested tech leaders at the game they invented, how so?

REP. RO KHANNA, D-CALIF.: Well, Trump was very effective in using Twitter and Facebook to get passionate support to get his message out.

But a lot of these platforms, of course, we're abused. They amplified fake voices, extreme voices that pretended to be 10,000 people even though there was only one person they've crafted in false news.

And so tech needs to help figure out how to solve some of these issues. We know it can empower individuals in extraordinary ways but we need to fix the excess that we saw in the 2016 election cycle.

CHANG: Right, you say tech tools should strengthen not weaken democracy and Russia interference aside. Someone argue that, you know, social media has dramatically increase the number of voices that are being heard. You know, can tech companies really be responsible for all of this?

KHANNA: Well, I actually think tech has played a very positive role overall. I mean, it gave a rise -- give rise to Barack Obama and to Bernie Sanders.

I often joke at town halls that the average person could have more of a voice by having a clever tweet or Facebook posts than I can by speaking to an empty chamber in congress.

So tech has empowered individuals in extraordinary ways, but that said there are things that now that they have become a platform where almost 50 percent of Americans get their news there that they need to do.

One if having some basic differentiation between fact and opinion on newspapers, TV stations like yours have third-party verification and they independently checked facts.

There can be third-party verification on some of the posts. They should look at providing perhaps an alternative perspective if viewers want that alternative perspective.

They just need to look at what their journalistic responsibilities can be without suppressing the freedom of expression.

And I'm encouraged that the number of tech companies are doing that and that dialogue has begun.

CHANG: You wonder though how far these companies can go? How well companies can distinguish between fact and opinion when our own president may have a different opinion of the facts than the facts?

KHANNA: I agree, it's a very difficult issue. But there are independent third-party sites which can at least rate content so if some part one that's out there saying the sky is green or that, you know, Barack Obama isn't an American citizen.

They could at least have a rating and verification. Just like newspapers do, just like television stations do where they could provide a link to say, "Here are some alternative perspectives if you saw the truth."

I think these tech companies -- tech company and social media is very different than television.

Television is an as interactive, people aren't responding to me. It's a broadcast, two individuals and tech is a person-to-person communication.

So tech can't be responsible for every single post in the content of every single post.

That said they do need to move towards adopting some journalistic standards of third-party verification, fact verification so they could give users an informed perspective.

CHANG: That said, I wonder how much can we rely on companies to do the right thing or whatever is in the best interest of society rather than what's in the best interest of their business.

And how much should the government actually be in charge of figuring out whether there's Russia interference on these platforms? Should there be government regulation?

KHANNA: Well, I think there are two different questions. In terms of the best interest of society, I think that was Silicon Valley's tradition with David Packard and Hewlett-Packard and some of the early founders, Andy Grove.

They talked about building technology in a way that would help society, help empower people.

And if you talk to tech leaders that's what they really hope that their platforms would help improve communication, lead to a more connected world, create more jobs.

Tim Cook recently said that business leaders have a moral responsibility to care about education and jobs.

Sundar Pichai recently announced a one billion dollar initiative to prepare folks for the tech jobs of the future.

And so I think there is an ongoing awareness with tech leaders that they have to care about their contribution to jobs in places that don't have them and to the democratic conversation.

Given that they are some of the largest companies in the nation and some of them have such great responsibility in so many viewers.

On the Russia issue, I think their -- we definitely need better intelligent sharing between tech companies and the government so that they can get advance notice if there is suspicious activity and act on it.

And tech companies need to help adapt exceptional processing to look at false accounts or bad accounts, bad actors, the way some bank (INAUDIBLE)

Some of it is hiring more people, but even if they hire a thousand of more people given the volume, they probably need investments in machine learning and artificial intelligence to be able to do some of that work.

So I'm hopeful a lot of it will be tech coming to its own conclusion but some -- there will probably be a role for congress and lawmakers as well to have constructive rules that tech can follow.

CHANG: Similarly, you talk about the importance of increasing diversity at these companies upward mobility, is this something that you think companies can do on their own?

We know that the representation of women in minorities at tech companies is very low or is this something that the government should regulate?

KHANNA: Well, I think it's in the tech companies own advantage to expand their imagination in recruiting. Let me give you a concrete example, 45 percent of African-Americans who have STEM degrees go to a historically black college or university, 45 percent.

Now, if tech companies want to expand where there's talent, they should form partnerships with some of the best historically black colleges and universities in the country and recruit from there.

The NFL in the 1960s, the Oakland Raiders did that. They started recruiting at the HPCUs and it gave them a whole competitive advantage over the rest of the teams in the NFL.

At the time where it have such scarcity for engineers and tech talent and everyone is concern that Google and Facebook and Apple is getting all the talent, expanding the pool and going to places to like HPCUs would make a difference. Same with in -- you know, go ahead.

CHANG: But the question -- the question is whether or not they should, it's whether the government should force them to do so or legislate, you know, various requirements for representation of women in minorities in your ranks?

KHANNA: Well, I'm not for quote our government regulating that but I do think government can make investment and women's schools that focus on STEM and HPCUs in providing greater opportunities and pathways in getting incentives for corporate mentorship for women leaders.

I think government can incentivize the creation of the pipeline and in getting people in to those leadership ranks.

But I don't think they should regulate a number of that tech companies have to fill as a quote I think that will be going too far.

CHANG: All right. Representative Ro Khanna, thank you so much for joining us. Great to have you here on the show.

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

REP. RO KHANNA, D-CA, PARTICIPATES ON A PANEL ON MSNBC "KASIE DC"

MAY 12, 2019

SPEAKERS: REP. RO KHANNA, D-CA

PHILIP RUCKER, WASHINGTON POST

JUANITA TOLLIVER, CENTER FOR AMERICAN PROGRESS

JACKIE ALEMANY, WASHINGTON POST

KASIE HUNT, MSNBC

[*] KASIE HUNT, MSNBC HOST: Welcome to the second hour of KASIE DC.

Joining me here on set: a member of the House OversightCommittee and co-chair of Senator Bernie Sanders's presidentialcampaign, Democratic Congressman Ro Khanna of California,"Washington Post" White House bureau chief and MSNBC politicalanalyst Philip Rucker, campaign director for the Center for AmericanProgress Action Fund, Juanita Tolliver, and author of "TheWashington Post's" "Power Up" newsletter, Jackie Alemany.

In real-time and full public view, Congress and the White Houseare testing the limits of their power. Phil and Jackie's colleaguesat "The Washington Post" report that President Trump and his alliesare working to block more than 20 separate investigations byDemocrats into his actions as president, his personal finances, andhis administration's policies.

House Democrats say the Trump administration has failed torespond to or comply with at least 79 requests for documents orother information. The president is blocking aides from testifying,refusing entire document requests from some committees, filinglawsuits against corporations to bar them from responding tosubpoenas, and asserting executive privilege to keep informationabout the special counsel's Russia investigation out of public view.And one of the points that the piece makes is that somecongressional experts fear the strategy could undermine theinstitutional power of Congress for years to come.

But, Congressman Khanna, what is the strategy here forDemocrats as you simply watch the president refuse request afterrequest after request and subpoena after subpoena?

REP. RO KHANNA (D-CA): Well, Kasie, it's an assault on the ideaof separation of powers. Look, every administration pushes backagainst Congress. That's normal and you have these fights. But noadministration denies every single request. That's what's going onhere. They are simply refusing to recognize Congress' role ofoversight.

There is only one thing we can do, and that's the courts.

HUNT: Is there a risk there? I mean, what is the kind ofthinking behind the scenes as to how to approach that withoutgetting a court decision that stops you in your tracks?

KHANNA: Well, I think the courts will rule clearly for us,because the law is clear. Unless there is national security atstake, when there are issues of obstruction or corrupt action in theexecutive branch, the Congress has clear ability to get thesedocuments. And I think courts are ruling expeditiously. We just hadthe D.C. court -- a court in D.C. say that they aren't going tostonewall. So, I expect that the courts will rule for us, andthey'll rule expeditiously.

HUNT: Juanita, you kind of worked in the Center for AmericanProgress which is very in touch, of course, with the base of theDemocratic Party. What's your view of how Democrats in Congressare kind of going about this and whether they should be moreaggressive than perhaps they're being?

JUANITA TOLLIVER, CENTER FOR AMERICAN PROGRESS FUND CAMPAIGNDIRECTOR: I mean, Democrats in Congress are operating off themandate in which they retook the house from voters overwhelminglysupporting Democrats in the midterms in 2018. And so, they'reactually really doing a great job of conducting that oversight. Ofcourse, there is tension on how far to go, but I think recentpolling showed that a lot of Democratic voters really want to waitfor additional evidence. They want the oversight to run its course.

And so I think it's really falling in line with what we've seenfrom Speaker Pelosi and Democratic leadership on Congress that hey,steady the course. Let's tow that line because let's not -- we'renot going to fall into the trap that Trump wants us to by pullingthe ultimate card of impeachment.

HUNT: Jackie, I mean, Pelosi said this week that the presidentis trying to goad Democrats into impeachment. But at the same time,they seem to be moving the line a little bit, closer and closer.

JACKIE ALEMANY, AUTHOR, "POWER UP" NEWSLETTER, THE WASHINGTONPOST: That's exactly right. Over the past few weeks, where you havereally seen Pelosi's position evolve here. She was prettyconservative at first, and now, she's using terms likeself-impeachment and goading.

But if you notice that language really puts the burden back onthe president because I think she still is hesitant here. There isimmense frustration amongst Democrats. I'm sure you can speakbetter to that than I can, but, you know, there is clearly an issueenforcement mechanisms working here.

And, you know, at the end of the day, this is a fight that thepresident wants to be having. He'd much rather be talk aboutfighting these oversight battles than talking about, you know, thecrises going on in Venezuela, China, North Korea, Iran, and Russia.

HUNT: Is that -- I mean, is that sort of the thinking behindthe scenes here, Phil, that this is good ground for the president tobe on to solidify his base?

PHIL RUCKER, MSNBC POLITICAL ANALYST: Absolutely, because hecan make himself the victim and the persecuted, and he can arguethat the Democrats are reaching beyond what is reasonable in theCongress to investigate him, and to try to force him out of officesomehow.

HUNT: We are losing our light here is in our studio. Sorry,Phil. We didn't mean to interrupt you. I think we're still on theair. But to all of our viewers who are now watching us in the dark,I sincerely apologize.

All right. I think we're back. So, we'll keep going. I know.

(CROSSTALK)

HUNT: Better look out. Maybe there is dragons outside thestudio somewhere.

Phil, I'm so sorry you were interrupted. Please continue.

RUCKER: One thing we should really keep in mind, though, is thescope and breadth of these investigations. There are 20investigations. It's not just about Russia and obstruction ofjustice and interference in the election, but it's looking into thesecurity clearance process at the White House. You know, how is itthat Jared Kushner and Ivanka Trump got their security clearancesdespite the objections of career staff?

It's looking into the president's personal finances, his taxreturns. Who does he owe money to? Where is that money coming from?These are accountability measures that were missing in the first twoyears of the administration because the Republicans controlled bothhouses of Congress. And the Democrats are trying to catch up.

HUNT: Congressman, I mean, what -- how far would you say thisline is moving? I mean, is your caucus in general when you guys gettogether behind the scenes -- I mean, Nancy Pelosi has her finger onthe pulse of that.

KHANNA: She does.

HUNT: You know, unlike anyone. And to hear her moving in thisdirection tells me there is something building inside your caucus.How strong is it at this point?

KHANNA: Well, there is greater and greater frustration. I mean,there was first frustration when the ten counts of obstruction weredetailed. Then there is frustration when the president refuses tocomply with anything and is basically insulting members of Congressand our constitutional duty.

But Nancy Pelosi is very clear. The speaker believes we need tohave public sentiment with us, and we are to make that case. And shewill move when public sentiment moves. She quotes Abraham Lincolnall the time. Public sentiment is everything.

So, she is -- anyone who knows her knows how she is looking atthis. She wants to build a case and then she is going to see wherepublic sentiment is.

HUNT: I mean, Jackie, what's your sense of -- I mean, having-- I know you look at the polling when you put together yournewsletter and all that. I mean, public sentiment has not movedtowards -- in favor of impeachment.

ALEMANY: No, it hasn't. And you even have people like SenatorSanders who are saying to voters on the campaign trail, even thoughhe's -- you know, he's trying to fund-raise off the Muellerreport, he's saying to voters, when we're talking about Mueller,when we're talking about all of these oversight pushes, we're nottalking about health care and issues that affect the American peopleon a consistent basis.

And so, I think Speaker Pelosi does realize that the more timeeveryone is spending, the more air time everyone is spending ontalking about these fights feeds into what the president is talkingabout, it helps distract from issues of health care -- trade, taxissues, of potentially repealing the president's tax bill.

HUNT: We get that bombshell "New York Times" report on thepresident's finances. The push for more details is also going on.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM (R-SC): In his mind, he is wildlysuccessful. That's part of his branding, is to be bigger than life.By any reasonable definition, he is successful. He is the presidentof the United States. He owns a bunch of golf courses that are a lotof fun to play. So, the American people figure out about what theywant to believe or not believe about Donald Trump and his marketing.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HUNT: On Tuesday, a federal judge is expected to rule onwhether the president can put a stop to a House subpoena demandingfinancial records from his personal accounting firm. And the waysand means committee issued subpoenas Friday to Treasury SecretarySteve Mnuchin and IRS Commissioner Charles Rettig by this comingFriday.

Over the weekend, the president reflected on the politicaloptics of it all, tweeting, quote: I won the 2016 election partiallybased on no tax returns while I'm under audit, which I still am,and the voters don't care making it a part of the 2020 election.

And here is what the IRS commissioner said one month ago.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. SANFORD BISHOP (D-GA): But there is no rule that wouldprohibit the release of a tax return because it's under audit.

CHARLES RETTIG, IRS COMMISSIONER: I'm not aware of such arule. And I believe I've answered that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HUNT: And let's just be clear in terms of fact checking thepresident, Juanita, that, first of all, presidents are auditedregularly. And yet we still see tax returns from past residents and,of course, the IRS commissioner did some fact checking for us theresaying there is nothing preventing this. But at the same time, itdoesn't necessarily seem as those Democrats have a clear pathforward to actually getting these released.

TOLLIVER: Well, I think the clear path forward is what they'redoing already, issue the subpoena, make the request, because whatthey've done now is looped in the IRS commissioner who is notbeholden to Trump the way Mnuchin is. And so, it's really callingon people further down the chain of command. Hey, are you reallygoing to put yourself on the line, put your future on the line toprotect a president who is hiding something at this point, and folkshave reason to believe?

And I think also in terms of public opinion on this, in pollsover the last four to six weeks, there is shown that the majority ofAmericans do believe that Trump should release his tax returns. Ithink Democrats have that going in their favor too.

HUNT: Phil, what of these is the most dangerous for thepresident? I mean, is Democrats going after his tax returns, thebiggest, you know, non-Russia problem that he has coming from theHill or not?

RUCKER: You know, it might be the most embarrassing problem forhim so far as if the returns from the more recent years show thatthe 10-year span that "The New York Times" reported on, it wouldshow that the president is not as rich as he says he is, and that hehad a lot of losses and is not the grand golden success that he haspitched himself to the American people as. But I don't know thatthat's politically that dangerous for him, or legally that'sdangerous for him.

If I were President Trump, I would be much more concerned aboutpeople like Don McGahn coming in to an open forum and testifying onany number of issues where the president could be implicated, andnot only bad behavior, but obstruction of justice or other criminalbehavior.

HUNT: Yes, the kicker of that "New York Times" report about histax returns, about how he said it was difficult to make money inreal estate. But his father never lost any money except when heinvested in his son.

Anyway, Phil Rucker, thanks so much for being here. We're sorryagain about the lights.

Everyone else is going to stay with us.

So, you have heard this week calls to break up Facebook, evenfrom one of the company's founders. Now it is turning into a wedgefor 2020 candidates in what has been a pretty tame election cyclejust got a little more heated.

Plus, her identity as a covert CIA agent was leaked during theBush administration to settle a political score against her husband.Now, Valerie Plame is running for Congress. She joins me live aheadon KASIE DC.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

HUNT: The battle over big tech's accountability problem is nowspilling into the presidential race and pitting 2020 Democratsagainst each other. Senator Cory Booker is making clear he doesn'tthink breaking up tech giants, which Elizabeth Warren has proposed,is a solution. But it's how Booker describes his disagreement withWarren's proposal that turned heads.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. CORY BOOKER (D-NJ), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: I don't thinkthat a president should be running around pointing at companies atcompanies and say breaking them up without any kind of process here.It's not me and my own personal opinion about going after folks.That sounds like a Donald Trump thing to say. I'm going to breakup you guys.

No. We need to create systems and processes.

INTERVIEWER: You just compared Elizabeth Warren to DonaldTrump?

BOOKER: I most certainly did not. She's my friend --

INTERVIEWER: That's what she's saying. She's the onethat's saying that.

BOOKER: Well, again, she has -- let her discuss and debate herpositions. I'm telling you right now, we do not need a presidentthat is going to use their own personal beliefs and tell you whichcompanies we should break up. We need a president who is going toenforce antitrust laws in this country.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HUNT: The call to reduce the power of big tech grew loud theirweek when Facebook co-founder Chris Hughes called the company,quote, dangerous. Hughes wrote in a "New York Times" op-ed that thegovernment must, quote, break up Facebook's monopoly.

And this morning, Senator Kamala Harris was also asked to weighin.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. KAMALA HARRIS (D-CA), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: There is noquestion in my mind that there needs to be serious regulation, andthat has not been happening there needs to be more oversight thathas not been happening.

INTERVIEWER: You think they should be broken up?

HARRIS: Yes, I think we have to seriously take a look at that,yes.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HUNT: Quite some comments from Cory Booker.

Congressman, I know you represent Silicon Valley. So, I want toget your take on this in a minute.

But, Jackie, just to kind of look at this from the lens of CoryBooker essentially calling Elizabeth Warren Trumpian in her kind ofattack on this on Facebook. At the same time, I mean, it isn't justany random company that she might have a personal vendetta against.

ALEMANY: No, it's not. And this has been Elizabeth Warren'spretty consistent position. It is really interesting as the campaignprogresses to finally see positions, different positions betweencandidates in the Democratic Party differentiating from themselves.Cory Booker sort of, you know, appearing to take actually the sidesof corporations a little bit more than Elizabeth Warren, which Ithink is a standpoint that you could have surmised from theirpositions in Congress.

But, you know, they both are part of a Congress that has failedreally to regulate Facebook over the last few years, and I thinkboth of them really need to grapple with their role in that. Youknow, France just finished their review in which the governmentconducted a six-month review internally in Facebook overseeing howtheir regulatory processes work and actually provided a report whichZuckerberg praised. And so, I don't think these two things, breakingup Facebook and increasing regulation are necessarily mutuallyexclusive.

HUNT: Yes, Congressman, to that point about Congress -- I mean,do you think that the United States Congress is equipped to regulatethese big tech companies, specifically Facebook? Are they capable ofit?

KHANNA: We need to have more technology and knowledge. But weneed to look to the Microsoft case. I think that was an example thatworked, that government went after Microsoft. They said you couldn'ttie Internet Explorer to Windows. If you had done that, theMicrosoft --

HUNT: We would all have to use Internet Explorer and our liveswould be way harder and --

(CROSSTALK)

(LAUGHTER)

KHANNA: Google would never have emerged, right? But it went tothe D.C. Circuit, and the D.C. Circuit said you don't have breakthem up. You need to make sure they can't do bad mergers, they can'tbe privileging their own platforms. So, there may be kind of ground.

I do think Elizabeth Warren has added a lot to the debate. Imean, she has called for stronger, thoughtful regulation. Thequestion is, how do we get there? And I think the Microsoft caseoffers the paradigm.

HUNT: I'm going to put you a little bit on the spot here.

KHANNA: Sure.

HUNT: And I will admit that, you know, I'm not intimatelyfamiliar with where Bernie Sanders stands on this question. But youare co-chair of his campaign. Where does he fall on the spectrum ofthese 2020 candidates?

KHANNA: I haven't asked him specifically. He usually focuses onWall Street and defense contractors and airline industries. I mean,I don't know his exact position on this. But I do know when he talksabout technology, he often talks about how do we get universalbroadband, how do we get technology into rural communities and jobsthere. But you'd have to ask him or his campaign --

HUNT: Well, you are his campaign. That's why I'm asking you.

KHANNA: I'm one of his co-chairs. I don't want to -- Idon't want to misrepresent his nuanced view on this without talkingto him about it.

HUNT: So, when it comes to the idea of breaking up Facebook, Imean, I think a lot of people, sort of, you know, Chris Hughesreally turned heads because to explore your Microsoft analogy alittle further, I mean, you're talking about a centralization ofpower that is much different from a company that is sellingcomputers and softwares to consumers, right? You're instead talkingabout the fact that because all these people are using thisplatform, the platform itself has immense power.

How do you actually -- I mean, you must have to take steps thatare slightly different than what happened in the Microsoft case toactually make it work.

KHANNA: Well, I think if you had scrutiny on mergers, right, Ithought they shouldn't have been allowed to acquire Instagram. Ithought they shouldn't have been allowed to acquire WhatsApp. And ifyou have different social media platforms, then you a choice.

I mean, I don't think it's the end of the world if someonedoesn't use Facebook. It would be the end of the world if someonedidn't have access to the Internet. That's why Facebook is autility. It's not like water or electricity.

HUNT: Well, for a lot of small businesses, it does serve apurpose like a utility does.

KHANNA: Well, I think that there have to be regulations so thatthey shouldn't be able to privilege their own products, theyshouldn't be able to bully vendors.

HUNT: They certainly bully the news industry in some cases aswell.

KHANNA: And I think that should be looked at. But what we haveto do is have a fact-based investigation and then have thoughtfulregulation on privacy, on making sure that they're not privilegingtheir platform, on making sure they're not getting a favorable dealagainst vendors.

But here is -- you say well, why not just break them up? Thereare two reasons. One, you don't want China, Alibaba, Tencent andBaidu to become the social media platforms around the world. I mean,there is some competition there and --

HUNT: Do you think Facebook views itself as fundamentallyAmerican? Because sometimes when I talk to my sources who workthere, they view themselves more as a global company than anAmerican one. I mean, how important do you think that Americanidentity is to Mark Zuckerberg?

KHANNA: I think they know they are an American company becausethey would never have succeeded under Chinese or European laws. Imean, it's the American First Amendment and Section 230 thatallowed a lot of these Internet companies to emerge. They aren'tcensored. They have a much more competitive environment than Europeallows.

So, I think they understand that their success, they owed it toAmerica, and they want to make sure some of those values continue.

Now, do they need to be more accountable? Absolutely. They needto do a better job to prevent interference from foreign actors. Theyneed to do a better job to protect privacy. They need to do a betterjob to create jobs and not just in my district, but across thecountry.

They need to hire more people of color. It's dismal what thehiring is of African Americans, African-American women.

So there are a lot of issues we can talk about. But we alsoshould look at their success. The #MeToo movement wouldn't havehappened in the extent it did without Facebook. Black Lives Matterused Facebook. Barack Obama, Bernie Sanders, Donald Trump, they alluse Facebook.

You know, Josh Hawley, the senator from Missouri, criticizingTitter saying we don't need it. Well, why don't you get off theplatforms then? Of course the social media platforms have beencritical to democracy. We need to make sure that they're doing it ina positive way.

HUNT: Well, it seems like the question whether they havefundamentally, Juanita, undermined democracy by empoweringauthoritarians and misinformation.

TOLLIVER: I think that's exactly right. With 2020 electioncoming up, all sorts of alarm bells are going off. Will our electionbe interfered in through this platform of Facebook, something that Ithink there has been a lot of evidence of? So how are user databeing protected? How are consumers being protected, folks like youand me who use these platforms?

I think the other thing here is these candidates, while they'reon a spectrum, still belief in those same fundamental components,protect consumer data, ensure innovation in the industry and makesure that this platform is working for the American good.

HUNT: All right. Congressman Ro Khanna, thank you very much forcoming on.

KHANNA: Thank you.

HUNT: It was always great, this particular conversation, it'svery interesting to have with you.

END
